The domain of a function is the set of all possible input values for which the function is defined. Every input value in the domain has a corresponding output in the codomain via the function.

An algebraic subset of \(\bar{K}^{n}\) defined over \(K\) is the set of common zeros in \(\bar{K}^{n}\) of the polynomials belonging to a subset \(E\) of the polynomial ring \(K[X]=K\left[X_{1}, \ldots, X_{n}\right]\). It is denoted as \(V(E)\).
Does the concept of a/an Domain need to be defined for a definition of a/an Algebraic subset to make sense? (True if the first concept is needed and False if is not.)

Explanation: The definition of an Algebraic subset involves the set of common zeros of polynomials from a subset of a polynomial ring over a field K. This definition focuses on the zeros of polynomials in an algebraic closure of K, denoted as \(\bar{K}^{n}\), and does not directly involve the concept of a domain as defined in the context of functions. The concept of a domain in the definition provided pertains to functions and their input values, which is distinct from the concept of zeros of polynomials in an algebraic geometry context. Therefore, understanding or defining an Algebraic subset does not require the concept of a domain as defined for functions.
